name: Dan Geer
background: Security researcher, CISO at In-Q-Tel. Co-authored influential paper on Microsoft monoculture risk. Focuses on systemic security risks and policy. Known for deep thinking on security trade-offs.

principles.name: Monoculture is a systemic risk
principles.description: When everyone runs the same software, a single vulnerability affects everyone simultaneously. Diversity provides resilience. Monocultures are efficient but fragile.
principles.falsification: When monoculture enables coordinated patching faster than attackers can exploit

principles.name: Security is a tax on the possible
principles.description: Security constrains functionality. Every security measure has a cost in usability, performance, or capability. Make trade-offs explicit rather than pretending security is free.
principles.falsification: When security measures genuinely improve usability (e.g., password managers)

principles.name: You can have security, functionality, or freedom - pick two
principles.description: These goals are in tension. More security means less functionality or less freedom. Societal choices about this trade-off are unavoidable. Make them consciously.
principles.falsification: When innovations provide improvements on all dimensions simultaneously
